title: Effects of language training on children's use of complex syntax
abstractText:
The overall aim of this project is to refine our current understanding of the relationship between the structural complexity of children's language and the linguistic input that they receive from adults.

One-hundred 6-year-olds will participate in two studies testing whether exposure to oral narratives with a high ratio of subordinate clauses will lead to an increase in the use of these subordinates in their own retelling of similar narratives.

The project is divided into three phases:

  • In phase 1 the children will be tested for their comprehension of words and of language structure through standardised tests. Their use of subordinates will also be tested through the elicitation of narratives.
  • In phase 2 the children will be divided into two groups: the experimental group will be exposed to narratives containing a high proportion of subordinate clauses; the control group will listen to narratives with a high ratio of coordinate clauses.
  • In the third and final phase the children will be tested again to evaluate whether the experimental group benefitted from the intensive exposure to subordinate clauses.

The hypothesis is that there should be a significant increase over time in the experimental group, but not in the control group.
